Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Magnetization Dynamics and Damping in Magnetic Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
****NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
This Faculty Early CAREER award funds research to investigate magnetization dynamics as well as the damping of the magnetization in magnetic nanostructures. A better understanding of the magnetization dynamics and its damping in magnetic nanostructures is of fundamental importance for the research area of spintronics, which targets the use of a quantum mechanical property of the electron known as "spin" to develop electronic devices with new functionality. In this context the damping of the magnetization will be a key factor, for example, to minimize the overall power consumption of spintronic devices. This project will investigate established material systems as well as new materials, but will also investigate the feasibility of high frequency biosensing using magnetic nanoparticles, which would have a number of possible applications. This project will seamlessly integrate education activities at all levels of education through research experiences for local high-school and undergraduate students and training of graduate students. In addition online educational material pertaining to this CAREER project will be designed and developed and will be made accessible for the general public.

****TECHNICAL ABSTRACT****
Understanding the magnetization dynamics and damping in magnetic nanostructures is of fundamental importance for many aspects of spintronics, a research area that targets the use of the electron spin to implement new electronic devices. This Faculty Early CAREER award funds research to investigate the magnetization dynamics and damping in magnetic nanostructures. Broadband ferromagnetic resonance techniques will be used to investigate the magnetization dynamics and damping in: (a) ferromagnet/antiferromagnet structures including systems modified using ion irradiation, expected to provide new insights in the role of two-magnon scattering in these structures; (b) new spintronic materials including B2 ordered alloys, aimed at providing guidance for the future development of low damping materials; (c) magnetic nanoparticles, aimed at investigating the feasibility of high frequency biosensing. This project will seamlessly integrate education activities at all levels of education through research experiences for local high-school and undergraduate students and training of graduate students. In addition online educational material pertaining to this CAREER project will be designed and developed and will be made accessible for the general public.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has advanced our understanding of the magnetization dynamics and relaxation in magnetic nanostructures. As part of the project, we have developed unique broadband ferromagnetic resonance techniques that have provided important new insights regarding the magnetization dynamics of numerous material systems. So far eleven publications directly related to the project have been published in high-impact journals, with more currently submitted and in preparation. This project has resulted in over forty conference contributions and numerous invited presentations at professional meetings, universities, national labs and industry partners. In particular, this project has provided important new insights regarding the relaxation in ferromagnets exchange coupled to antiferromagnets. We have studied in detail the mechanisms responsible for the unidirectional contribution to the relaxation and we were able to show how this contribution can be utilized in multilayers to obtain a frequency selective response of the system. Our broadband capabilities have enabled the characterization of numerous other materials relevant for spintronic applications, in particular for spin transfer torque magnetic random access memories and hard drive read heads. This includes for example studies of the perpendicular anisotropy, damping and spin polarization in B2 ordered CoFeAl based alloys, Cr-diluted CoFeB, Co2FeSi and Fe2CoSi thin films. In addition, we were able to carry out detailed studies of the magnetic properties of nickel ferrite, lithium ferrite, Yttrium iron garnet, and magnetite.
The project has also enabled us to summarize some of the important aspects regarding the relaxation in magnetic materials as a book chapter, which has recently been published.

Two Ph.D. theses were completed as part of this project. In addition, the project has contributed to the education of three female and three male undergraduate students and to the education of one minority high school student. The project also provided a research opportunity for a faculty member from an HBCU institution. The broadband ferromagnetic resonance capabilities will continue to provide a wide variety of research opportunities for high school, undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Alabama. The capabilities developed as part of this project will continue to have an impact on the instrumentation in this research field as they offer high sensitivity and a broad frequency range to carry out ferromagnetic resonance experiments in a single instrument. The technology and methodology to carry out broadband ferromagnetic resonance measurements have also been adopted by several industry collaborators of the PI.

Modified by: Tim Mewes

As part of the project, we have developed unique broadband ferromagnetic resonance techniques that have provided important new insights regarding the magnetization dynamics of numerous material systems. Our broadband capabilities have enabled the characterization of numerous other materials relevant for spintronic applications, in particular for spin transfer torque magnetic random access memories and hard drive read heads. In addition, we were able to carry out detailed studies of the magnetic properties of nickel ferrite, lithium ferrite, Yttrium iron garnet, and magnetite.
